Award.AwardTitle: A National Initiative to Bring Science and Sustainability to the Incarcerated: A Conference Grant

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This conference project features two gatherings of scientists, science educators, and other experts, as well as the development of a web site, list-serv, and related activities. During the gatherings, participants will explore how to build state-based programs that can engage people who are incarcerated in sustainability science programming.

This work builds off of the success of the Sustainable Prisons Project, which has connected people who are incarcerated in Washington State with science through direct involvement in conservation research, and responds to calls from scientists and corrections staff interested in implementing similar programming in other states. The project will help advance the informal science education (ISE) field by potentially leading to high impact activities for a truly underserved population; building capacity among ISE professionals; and building knowledge and a replicable model of supporting non-traditional collaborations that serve the needs of people underrepresented in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Conference goals are to explore how science educators, scientists, and conservation/sustainability experts can engage incarcerated populations in ways that benefit an understanding and appreciation for science, conservation biology/sustainability, the corrections community, and the environment. This project builds off of the existing Sustainability in Prisons Project (SPP) implemented in 2004 in Washington State.

We: 1) gathered representatives from many states/counties, including individuals from academia, conservation, and corrections, to learn about SPP and develop action plans for bringing SPP to their home states and institutions; 2) developed a vision and action plan for a national SPP Network; and 3) developed and maintained a communication pathway among individuals and institutions at membership nodes, and to serve as a source of information and a repository for reports and results. 

Co-led by existing initiatives in Washington State and Utah’s Initiatives, we hosted a two-part national conference. For the first workshop (2012), 45 participants representing 11 states, counties and national organizations, and 33 organizations and institutions in corrections, academia, sustainability, conservation, social justice, and correctional industries joined 33 partners at The Evergreen State College campus for two days. Activities included tours of programs at three western Washington prisons, presentations on SPP-WA history, tips for success, management strategies, program evaluation, and ideas for the SPP National Network. The visiting state/regional teams presented on their existing and planned programs. Each team also sought out new partnerships and connections, and began work on Action Plans for implementing or expanding programs based on the SPP model.

Nine correctional agencies (OR, CA, MD, UT, OH, and WA states; Multnomah, Los Angeles, and Santa Clara Counties) met in March, 2013 in Salt Lake City, Utah for the second phase of the national conference. Each presented reports on their progress and their state/regional Action Plans. These nine teams currently serve as our primary collaborators at the national level. We have also been fielding communications from more than twenty additional states (AL, AZ, CO, FL, GA, IA, ID, IL, IN, KY, MI, MO, NC, NE, NM, NY, NC, PA, SC, TX, VA, VT, and WV) and countries (Australia, Botswana, England, Fiji, France, Mexico, Moldova, Saipan, Seychelles, and Scotland). At the same time that we have been growing nationally and internationally, the original SPP has matured to a statewide effort. SPP programs are flourishing in all twelve Washington State Department of Corrections (WA DOC) prisons, and many new programs are in the works. These activities led to development of a vision statement and discussions for a sustainable long-term SPP-Network plan. An Advisory Board was established to provide oversight for SPP-Network activities. A peer-to-peer mentoring project provided support for staff from one state to visit and learn from another.
